I personally think that they're going after governors as a medium high-profile priority, not that others are ignored. Local elections are typically run out of state level parties, not national ones -which makes a lot of sense - and governors are more important than the house at the moment in a longer term strategy:
A) the house isn't going to flip soon, the majority is too strong, and there aren't enough seats to flip.
B) the governors (along with local races) will be instrumental in the 2020 gerrymander, so focusing control their is hugely more important than the house at this time. And that gerrymander will also allow for the house to flip in 2020/2022

Actually, one of the biggest things holding by 5G is vector processing. Ie, funding the direction and location where the device is.
5G will be run on much, much smaller wave length than previous generations, this efficiency allows more data and better bandwidth sharing/division to allow a much higher capacity data transmission.
The downside is that smaller waves dissipate much faster. This necessitates a more directionally addressed beam to allow for better transmission.
One way Qualcomm is trying to overcome this is by sending out a fishing signal, which will tell the antenna where the device is, and then the antenna can beam directly to the device with more amplitude, and allow for better range.
Beam formation is near the speed of light, so 150 mph is not very fast, and the signal beam will likely be 100s of times per second.

1st and business class tickets typically make up over 30% airline revenue. Aside from their high prices, those flyers will buy tickets based on scheduling (often last minute) rather than price sensitivity.
A first class ticket (1 way) for tomorrow morning from LA to London will cost $7k-$12k depending on the airline. Just 3-4 of those tickets, plus 8 business class tickets (6-10k) could be nealry $100,000 for that one flight
